content.description: Figure 1. The electron transport chain of cellular respiration. The bold arrows passing through the complexes in the membrane represent the path of electron flow in mitochondria.
content.question: Compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> binds to complex <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IV</mtext></math> of the mitochondrial electron transport chain and prevents complex <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IV</mtext></math> from accepting electrons. Based on Figure 1, which of the following best explains why the cells of an animal exposed to compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> have an increased ratio of <math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NADH</mi></math> to <math alttext="N A D with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>NAD</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NADH</mi></math> increases because compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> directly prevents <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math> synthase from producing the <math alttext="A T P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ATP</mi></math> necessary for the oxidation of <math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NADH</mi></math> to <math alttext="N A D with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>NAD</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup></math>.

<math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NADH</mi></math> increases because the binding of compound <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> to complex <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IV</mtext></math> also prevents the transport of <math alttext="N A D with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>NAD</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup></math> out of the mitochondria.

<math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NADH</mi></math> cannot be oxidized to <math alttext="N A D with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>NAD</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup></math> because complexes <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>III</mtext></math> cannot accept electrons if electrons cannot be passed to complex <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IV</mtext></math>.

<math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NADH</mi></math> cannot be oxidized to <math alttext="N A D with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>NAD</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup></math> because <math alttext="H 2 O" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>H</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub><mtext>O</mtext></math> cannot bind to the active site of complex <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IV</mtext></math> if this complex cannot accept electrons.

content.answer: <math alttext="N A D H" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>NADH</mi></math> cannot be oxidized to <math alttext="N A D with a positive one charge" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mtext>NAD</mtext><mo>+</mo></msup></math> because complexes <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math>, <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>III</mtext></math> cannot accept electrons if electrons cannot be passed to complex <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>IV</mtext></math>.

skill.text: 2.B: Explain relationships between characteristics of biological models in both theoretical and applied contexts.
